content: Hey folks -- so we're at T-3 weeks and counting -- I'm a bit confused about what outstanding problems, if any, there are.
I saw that @simulacrum was discussing doing another crater run in #edition 2021 > finalish crater run?
@simulacrum you also reported a few blockers in #edition 2021 > Edition Blockers(?), it was clear to me what action if any should result from those
The insignificant dtors is not yet tested on beta (e.g., by enabling the lint on the compiler and seeing how it does now), I think
That seems like a good step to take to close https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/89080
• https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/89135 will be fixed by backporting https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/89277, which just needs to happen
Do I remember correctly that you had a PR moving the compiler to Rust 2021, @simulacrum ?
OK, so it's more a matter of re-enabling the lint, and not migrating
but the 2229 lints can be enabled even post-migration (they don't care what edition code is in) so that seems like not a problem
I assume there wonâ€™t be any special marketing for the edition other than the normal change log blog post right? Do we want to work with the release team on that?

@cuviper is working on the post this cycle, I'm guessing help is appreciated though :)

We're trying to strike a delicate balance between putting focus on cool features in the edition and it's arrival and avoiding it being "too big" and hurting our message about editions not being forced breaking changes and such
I feel like we should target blog posts not about the Edition per se but about the individual changes within it
(and they can talk about the edition in passing)
that seems right to me as well
